title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 1 Assessment
description: Create an eCard that meets all of the following specifications:
Has a message for the viewer (such as "Happy New Year," "Happy Birthday," "Get Well Soon," etc.)
Has stage background and sprite costumes
Includes a custom block. This can be either:
A start over block that resets the eCard to the beginning (resets pen, stage, and sprites) OR
Another custom block containing multiple blocks that contributes to the purpose of the program (this could move a sprite, change the background, etc.)
Includes iteration through the use of the repeat, repeat until, or for block.
Lets the user interact (such as by clicking a sprite, pressing a key, or moving the mouse, etc.)
Includes one additional feature. For example, you can choose:
Sounds or music (using the play block and/or the "Sounds" tab)
The random block
Put a comment in your code identifying the additional feature and briefly describing what it does.

title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 2 Assessment
description: Create a survey project that meets all of the following specifications:
Collects data from the user by asking the user a specific question and gathering their response using the ask and answer blocks.
For example:
Stores the collected data in a list. Put at least ten example responses into the list yourself.
Processes the data to answer three research questions by using one or more of the following blocks:
keep
combine
the list-processing blocks you built in Lab 4 on Page 3:
maximum of list
minimum of list
sum of list
average of list
For example: If you asked “How many books have you read so far this month?” you could analyze the data to answer the following research questions:
What is the average number of books people have read so far this month?
What is the maximum number of books people have read so far this month?
How many people have read at least two books this month?

title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 3 Assessment
description: Similar to your work in Lab 3: Turning Data into Information, create a data project that meets all of the following specifications:
Stores and manipulates information by creating an abstract data type that uses lists within lists to store similar data about several different items.
For example, you can store the name, breed, and age of several dogs as shown in the image to the right.

Add new items to the list.
Clear the list.

title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 4 Assessment
description: Make an interactive poster in Snap! that meets all of the following specifications:
Serves one of the following purposes:
Teaches the user how the internet works OR
Warns the user about cybersecurity concerns OR
Informs the user about digital equity

Iteration, such as through the use of the repeat or for block.
Selection, such as through the use of an if or if else block.
A list which either stores data that is already programmed in or data that is collected from the user.

title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 5 Assessment
description: Similar to your work in Lab 2, Contact List, write a data analysis program that meets all of the following specifications:

Filters the data in a single column of a portion of your data set by using keep.

For example, you could determine the following:
The average value
The maximum value

title: Beauty and Joy of Computing Unit 8 Assessment
description: Write a recursive program in Snap!. Your recursive function should include the following:
A base case for the lowest level that stops the recursion from going on forever.
A recursive case that calls the block itself at lower levels until it reaches the base case.
Your program should have a clearly defined purpose and cannot be a duplicate of one you already wrote while completing the labs in  Unit 7 or Unit 8.
Some possible problems to solve include:

Write a program to calculate the Fibonacci sequence up to the nth number (where n is the input into the program). The Fibonacci sequence is a series of numbers where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, usually starting with 0 and 1. The sequence goes 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, and so forth.
Write a program to check if a word is a palindrome. A word that is a palindrome reads the same forward and backward. For example, "madam" or "racecar" are palindromes.
Write a program to reverse the characters in a string. For example, “goodnight” will become “thgindoog”.
Write a program to compute xn (x raised to the power n) recursively.
